caption: Table 1: Ablation study on Morph-MoMask (combined with MoMask [7] generator) for text-to-motion task on HumanML3D dataset. IS: imitation selection operation; Adversarial: using adversarial reward training MPR module; Energy: using energy reward training MPR module; Real Data: using real motion data training MPR module; FT: fine-tuning Motion Generator with physics-refined motions. The arrows (↑⁣/⁣↓↑↓\uparrow/\downarrow↑ / ↓) indicate that higher/smaller values are better.
description: This ablation study analyzes the impact of different components of the Morph framework, when combined with the MoMask motion generator, on text-to-motion generation using the HumanML3D dataset.  It examines the effects of the imitation selection operation (IS), the use of adversarial and energy rewards during training of the Motion Physics Refinement (MPR) module, and the use of real motion data versus synthetic data for training the MPR module. Finally, it evaluates the impact of fine-tuning (FT) the Motion Generator using physics-refined motions.  Higher values are better for metrics with an upward-pointing arrow (↑), and lower values are better for metrics with a downward-pointing arrow (↓).

caption: Table 4: Comparison results for music-to-dance on AIST++ dataset. ††\dagger† denotes Morph without fine-tuning motion generator.
description: Table 4 presents a comparison of the performance of different methods for music-to-dance generation on the AIST++ dataset.  The table shows results for several metrics, including common generation metrics (FIDk, FIDg, Divk, Divg, BAS) which evaluate the quality of the generated dance motions in terms of their fidelity to real human movement and their diversity. Additionally, the table includes physical plausibility metrics (PFC, Penetrate, Float, Skate, IFR) which assess the realism of the generated dance, considering factors like whether feet stay grounded, and whether the body exhibits physically implausible behaviour such as floating or penetration. Results are provided for several methods:  FACT, TM2D, EDGE, Bailando, and Morph combined with either EDGE or Bailando, with and without fine-tuning the motion generator. This allows for a comparison of the impact of incorporating a physics refinement module (Morph) on generation performance and physical realism.
